titleStmt.title: A diary of the siege of Colchester by the forces under the command of Generall Fairfax

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed and sold by Tho: Witham at the Golden Ball in Long Lane near West Smithfield,

notesStmt.note: A description of the Parliamentary Army's siege of Colchester, dated Tuesday, June 13 through Tuesday, August 22.
Consists of two engraved maps (2 sheets, 1‚Å∞), with engraved text surrounding the maps.
Reproduction of original in the Folger Shakespeare Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: A DIARY of the Siege of COLCHESTER by the Forces under the Command of Generall FAIRFAX.

div.p:
Tue≈øday June 13. The Lord Fairfax engaged in the fields bef ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Colche≈øter near S.t Maries, the Lord Gorings Forces, together with the Forces under Command of the Lord Capell, and Sir Charl's Lucas, and beat them into the Town; Colonell St. William Leyton and between 4 and 500 of ye Kings Forces were taken pri≈øoners. (200 of them being of Colonell Farrs Regiment.) and in pur≈øuit of the re≈øt. Col. Barke≈øtead, with his Regiment, entred the Suburbs as far as head-Gate, and entred ye Gate, but being overpowered there, and out of the Church-yard, ye Kings Forces Barracadoed the Gate. (leaving neer 500 men to our mercy:) yet notwith≈øtanding tho≈øe foot, and Col. Needhams fought many hours after in hopes to gain the Town at that place, but could not, the Kings Forces making good re≈øistance; there were ≈ølain of the Kings Forces, Col. Sir William Campion. Col. Cooke, and divers Officers of quality, and about 80 private soldiers; Col. Panton. Capt Brunkerd. Clifford, Wors op, and divers other Officers wounded. On General Fairfax's side Col. Needham. Capt. Lawrence of Horse. Capt. Cox of foot and neer 100 private souldiers and inferior Officers were ≈ølain: when we enter'd the Suburbs, the Lord Goring was Summoned but returned an Answer not becoming a Gentleman: The Word of the Kings Forces at ye Fight was Charles, the ground they fought upon. Maries: C ‚Ä¶ . Gods‚Äîour help.

div.head: The Forces under the Command of Generall Fairfax engaged in ye Fight before Colche≈øter, June 13. 1648 As also the names of the chief Commanders and persons of Quality of the Lord Gorings Forces engaged at that Fight.
Generall Fairfaxes Forces engaged in that Fight.
div.p: Part of the Generalls Regiment of Horse, being 4 Troops, Commanded by Major De≈øbrough. Of Col. Whaleys Regiment, 6 Troops, Commanded by himself. Of Col. Fleetwoods, 5 Troops, Commanded by Major Coleman. Three Troops of Commi≈øsary Genl. Iretons, Commanded by Captain Cecill. Two Troops of Dragoons, Commanded by Captain Freeman and Captain Barrington.

Of Foot. Col. Bark≈øteeds Regiment Commanded by him≈øelf, con≈øi≈øting of 10 Companies, about 800 men. Col. Needhams Regiment, lately the Tower Regiment, ComÃÑanded by Col. Needham, being 7 Companies, and about 400 men. Part of Col. Ingle≈øby's Regiment, of 4 Companies, Commanded by Capt. Grimes, 320 men.

Of the E≈ø≈øex Forces. Col. Harlackenden ‚Ä¢
Regiment, of 4 Troops of horse, Commanded by Major Robert Sparrow; and Captain Turners Troop of Dragoons. Sir Thomas Hunniwoods Regiment of Foot. Col. Cooks Regiment of Foot, both which said Regiments con≈øi≈øted of Auxiliaries, and Trained bands.
The County Forces of E≈ø≈øex left to secure Chelmsford and Man≈øden, two con≈øiderable Pa≈øses, left more Forces should resort from London to the Lord Goring.
Colonel Henry Mildmaies Regiment of Hor≈øe, and two Troops of Dragoons. Part of Col. Carew Mildmaies Regiment of Foot, Commanded by Major Bard.

The Suffolk Forces, who made good the Pa≈øses over the River at Nailand Stratford and Cadaway, le≈øt the Enemy ≈øhould e≈øcape towards Suffolk and Norfolk, were under the Command of Capt. Fi≈øher, Captain Bradling, and Captain Sparrow, be≈øides the a≈øsi≈øtance which Capt Ball, Capt. Cox, and the rest of the Sea Commanders gave to secure the River.
The Suffolk Forces that came afterwards to help be≈øiege this Town.
Colonel Gourdons Regiment of Horse.
Of Foot Regiments. Colonel Sir Thomas Barnadi≈øtons, Col. Fothergils, Col. Harveys, Col. Bloi≈øes.
Of the Army that came up after the Fight. Col. Scroop, with 3 Troops of hor≈øe of his Regiment

div.head: The Lord Gorings Forces engaged in that Fight.
div.p: Of Horse. Lord Gorings Regiment. Lord Capels Regiment. Sir William Comptons. Col. Sling≈øbies. Col. Sir Bernard Gascoignes. Colonel Hamonds. Colonel Culpeppers.

Of Foot. Sir Charles Lucas his Regimt. Sir George Li≈øles Regiment. Colonel Tilleys Regimt. Col. Tewk his Regiment. Col. Farrs Regiment. Colonel Gilburds Regiment. Col. Sir William Campions Regiment, him≈øelf ≈ølain. Colonel Burds Regiment. Colonel Bowmans Regiment. Col. Che≈øters Regiment.

div.head: Colonels who had no Commd. of Regiments, yet a≈øsi≈øting at that Fight.
div.p: Earl Louborough, Lord Ha≈øtings, Sir William Leyton, Colonel, taken Pri≈øoner, and wounded. Col. Sir Richard Ha≈øtings, Colonel Iohn Heath, Colonel Lee of Kent, Colonel Panton wounded, Colonel Cook ≈ølain. Colonel Sir Hugh Orelie, Quarter-ma≈øter Gen. Col. William-Mexey, Col. Pitman, Col. Beal, Lieu. Col. Hatch ≈ølain, Major Jammot, Adjutant Gen. be≈øides divers Lieutenant Colonels and Majors who were a≈øsi≈øtants, but had no Commands.

Wedne≈øday 14. Generall Fairfax perceiving the Lord Gorings Forces would not ≈øtand the field, re≈øolved to sit down before the Town in order to a Siege (but being too few to Storm it) having not then nor when he first engaged, 1500 old Foot, and but about 1500 Horse, and two Troops of Dragoons, (be≈øides the 2 Regiments of the Trained Bands, under Col Sir Thomas Hunniwood, and Col Cooke.) the Lord Gorings Forces at that time being about 6000 Horse & Foot in Town, and the Town and Suburbs larger in Compas than Oxford, and would require 5000 men to Be≈øiege it; appointed Lexden in the road to London for the Head-Quarter, where the greate≈øt Body was to lie, to prevent more aid for coming from London to the Lord Goring, and kept ≈øtrong Guards of Horse on Cambridge road on the other side the River, that they might not e≈øcape Northward to joyn with Sir Marmaduke Langdale, leaving no place open to them, but towards the Sea, where they could not go far; and the same day Our Generall sent a Party of Horse to secure Mer≈øey I≈øland, to prevent the Kings Ships from coming into the River to relieve the Town; the Be≈øieged sent Col. Tuke with a ≈øtrong Party an hour after,‚Äîbut came too late.

Thursday 15. The Be≈øiegeds Canon from the Royall Fort at St. Maries, plaid very hard killed severall of our men, as they did the day before; some, as they were rai≈øing the first Work called Fort E≈øsex, others as they were ≈øtragling in the field.
Friday 16: Nothing of importance happened, but. 3 of Capt. Canons men killed with a Canon Bullet.

Saturday 17. A Trumpet sent in about the Exchange of pri≈øoners, & this day the Be≈øieged got provi≈øions out of Tendering Hundred, which we could not prevent till ye Suffolk Forces march'd to our a≈øsi≈øtance.

Sunday 18. We took 2 of their Frigots, the one with 10. the other with 11 Guns: & this day Col. Ewers came up with 6 Companies from Chep≈øtow Ca≈øtle: The E≈øsex Foot under Sir Tho. Hunniwood & Col. Cooke endured many Canon ≈øhot this day, and were very ready upon an Alarm.

Munday 19. The party of Hor≈øe sent from the Leaguer under Major-Sparrow & Capt Wallingford engaged the Kings Forces at Linton. (coming to a≈øsi≈øt the Lord Goring.) where Major Muschampe & others of the Kings Forces were ≈ølain, & Ma≈øter Reynolds, & others taken pri≈øoners, the re≈øt (about 500.) disperst. This day a Trumpet came from ye Ld. Goring, prentending to de≈øire a Treaty of Peace.

Tue≈øday 20. Answer returned, if a generall Peace was intended, that then it was proper for the Parlament to determine of that, and offered them in that an≈øwer Conditions, Viz. The Gentlemen & Officers to go beyond ≈øea, and the Souldiers to go home, without prejudice.
Wedne≈øday 21. The Be≈øieged returned a ≈øcornfull an≈øwer, moving for a free-trade for the Town≈ømen.

Thursday 22. A ≈ømall Party of the Be≈øieged ≈øallied out to view a new Work (afterwards called Col. Ewers Fort)‚Äîbut were in≈øtantly beaten in by Mu≈øqueteers. Their Canon killed two men of ours. That day the Lord Goring ≈øent a summons to the Suffolk Forces at Callaway-Bridge, Commdd. by Capt. Fi≈øher, & Capt. Brandling, to joyn with him, which they refu≈øed Re≈øolving ≈øtill to adhere to the Parliament & Army.

Friday 23. The Guns began this day to play from our new Battery, which much annoyed the Be≈øieged at North bridge. Our Generall sent a Reply concerning his former offer, offering the same Conditions again to all in the Town, Except the Ld. Goring, Ld. Capell, and Sir Charles Lucas.

Saturday 24. One of the Be≈øiegeds Canoneers was killed. This day the Suffolk Forces advanced out of their own County, & took up their Quarters upon Mile-end, over again≈øt the North-gate, being about 2500 Hor≈øe and Foot, leaving a guard at Cattaway, and Nayland, to ≈øecure those pa≈øses.
Sunday 25. Nothing of importance.

Munday 26. A party of Col. Bark≈øteeds Foot (the Be≈øieged having drawn out near the Almes-house) beat them from ye Hedges, and from their Court of Guard, fired the Guard-hou≈øe, and brought away the hour-gla≈øs by which they ≈øtood Centry.
Tuesday 27. A Trumpeter went in with the Lady Campions Servant, with a Letter to her husband for ≈øhe did not beleeve he was ≈ølain.

Wedne≈øday 28. Chewed & Poysoned Bulletts taken from severall of the Be≈øieged. Affidavit made by those Souldiers of ye Besieged who brought them out of Colche≈øter, that they were given out by the Lord Gorings ≈øpeciall Command. The≈øe Examinations were ≈øent to ye Lord Goring, with this Me≈øsage from Our Generall, That his men ≈øhould expect no Quarter hereafter, if they used such Bullets. This day early in the morning the Be≈øieged, with a party of Hor≈øe, very boldly attempted our Horse Guards near St. Maries, ≈øhot a Scout, but were in≈øtantly beaten back.

Thur≈øday 29. They killed some Hors & Foot of ours with their great Canon as they ≈øhot against our men, at ye making of Col. Bark≈øteeds Fort, fired the House which was lately Sr. Harbottle Grim≈øtons, & at night fired Mr. Barringtons house, a party of the Be≈øiegeds Horse advanced over the Bridge at Ea≈øtgate, where Ambu≈øcadoes being laid for them by our Dragoon's, Lieut. Col. Hatcher, & divers other Officers & Souldiers of the Be≈øieged, upon their ha≈øty advance were ≈ølain: none on our part.
Friday 30. Exchange offered for Sir Will. Ma≈ø≈øam, but refused.
Saturday July 1. Col. Whaley po≈øsest Grin≈øted Church.
Sunday 2. Strong Guards kept that night to prevent the Be≈øiegeds escape Northward, we having notice of their intention.

Monday 3. & Tue≈øday 4. Little of moment happened, except a Porter; or Chamberlain coming from the Bell in Gratious-≈øtreet stole into the Town, with Intelligence of the Earl of-Hollands rai≈øing an Army in & about London for their relief.

Wedne≈øday 5. The Be≈øieged sallied out with a ≈øtrong party,‚ÄîCommanded by Sir George Li≈øle, ≈øurpri≈øed our Guard at Ea≈øtbridge, and gained two Drakes, but advanceing to ye Main Guard were routed by Col. Whaleys horse, Commanded by Major Swallow; 19 ≈ølain on the place, the Drakes recovered, and our former ground also; Lieut. Col. We≈øton, Lieut. Col. Weeks, and 80 & odd pri≈øoners were taken, mo≈øt of them sore cut for ≈øhooting poy≈øoned bullets (20 of them died the next day) On our part, we had slain Lieut. Col. Shambrooke, and some others of Col. Needhams Regiment, who were engaged, Capt. Moody on our ≈øide wounded & taken pri≈øoner, and one Lieutenant & En≈øign, & 40 private Soldiers of ours taken prisoners also.
Friday 7. Col. Scroop sent from the Leaguer by our Generall, with a Regiment of Horse, to engage the Forces under ye Duke of Buckingham and Earl of Holland: got into a body to rai≈øe ye Siege.

Saturday 8. News of Col. Ro≈ø≈øiters routing the Pontefract Forces at Willoughby field, where 3 Troops of the Army were engaged, & many of the men wounded; Colonel Generall Sir Philip Mouncton, Major Generall Biron, & divers Officers of quality taken prisoners by Colonell Ro≈ø≈øiter.

Sunday 9. News of the Earl of Holland, and Duke of Burckinghams being routed in Surrey, & of the Lord Villiers being ≈ølaue by Sir Michael Lever≈øey, & Major Gibbons, who Commanded a party of Horse of the Army.

Monday 10. Several of the Be≈øieged came away to us; new ‚Ä¢ came this day of the taking of 600 Horse in Northumberland, & of Sir Francis Ratcliff, Col. Tempe≈øt, Col. Grey, & other pri≈øoners, taken by Col. Lilburn.

Tuesday 11. We had a Gunner & a Matro≈øse ≈øhot, as they were battering St. Maries ≈øteeple. News came this day of ye Earl of Hollands being taken prisoner by Col. Scroop; & Sir Gilbert Gerrard, & others of quality, & that Col. Dalbeer was ≈ølain, and their whole force dispersed at S. Needs in Huntington ≈øhire.

The 12 & 13. Little of moment happened, only Mr. Iohn A≈øhburnham offered in exchange for Sir William Ma≈øsam, but not accepted; and this day the me≈øsenger who came to Our Generall with a Letter of the taking of Waymer Ca≈øtle in Kent, took his oppertunity, and carried it into Colche≈øter to the Lord Goring, and took up arms there.

Friday 14. The new Battery being raised again≈øt St. Iohns, from the Lord Lucas house, 2 pieces of Canon plaid thence, made a breach in the wall: The Souldiers entred, fell on immediately, drove the Be≈øieged out of the first Court-yard into the second, & thence into ye Gatehouse, and the same day a‚Äî ≈øtrong party of Hor≈øe & Foot fell upon the Hieth, & ≈øtormed the Church, & took all the Guard therein prisoners, being about 70. and that night we po≈ø≈øest our ≈øelves of the Hieth, & a great part of the Suburbs, which much troubled ye Be≈øieged: the Suffolk Foot did well in this service

Saturday 15. The Gate-house being a place very con≈øiderable, & mighty advantagious for us. Our Generall re≈øolved to storm the same, though it had a ≈øtrong work before it; whereupon 6 Souldiers, for 3 ≈øhillings a piece, undertook to throw in Granadoes, and 20 men to carry Ladders for half a Crown a piece, & a Commanded party of Foot to ≈øtorm, led on by Major Be≈øcoe, which accordingly they did as soon as 8 peice of Canon had given fire upon the Besieged, and the Granadoes did great execution the Ladders were placed with much advantage, the Be≈øieged much dismaied, forced to quit ther‚Äîworks, & flie into the Gate-house, one Granadoe kindled their Magazin, and blew up many of the Be≈øieged, the re≈øt were taken pri≈øoners, and ≈ølain; the pri≈øoners confest they were above a hundred in the Gate-house & work, and few of them could escape, 13 at one place were pulled out the next day from under the Rubbi≈øh. This night the Be≈øieged indeavoured to e≈øcape with their horse, Commanded by Sir Bernard Ga≈øcoign, and pa≈øt the River between the North-bridge & middle Mill, and had the Miller for their Guide, but ye Miller when he came int othe Clo≈øes, ran away, and the Pioneers after him, and our Centinels giving fire, the Be≈øieged retreated; The Suburbs was Fired in 6 or 7 places, which burnt in a most-dreadfull manner all night long, that the Town might be seen almo≈øt as well by night as by day, so great was the flame. And on Sunday the 16. other Streets were set on fire, with de≈øign to con≈øume the whole Suburbs, but by the indu≈øtry of the Inhabitants & Souldiers it was prevented. This day our Generall had certain Intelligence. That an Army of Scots under Duke Hamilton, had invaded the Kingdom & joyned the Cavaliers under Langdale.

Sunday 16. Our Generall sent a Summons again to Surrender the Town: The Lord Goring, Lord Capell, & Sir Charles Lucas joyntly returned Answer (in writing) under their hands to our Generall. That if the Trumpeter came any more with such a Summons, they would hand him up. The Conditions then offered to the Souldiers, was. Liberty, and Pa≈ø≈øes to go to their severall homes, submitting to the Authority of Parliament.

Munday 17. Again more hou≈øes were fired towards ye North ≈øtreet, & other places. This day our Generall had certain News brought him of the Surrender of Pembrook Town & Ca≈øtle, Langhorn, and Poyer submitting their lives to mercy.
Tuesday 18. Their Horse again attempted to break through towards the North, but were beaten in again.

Wedne≈øday 19. Seventeen of the Be≈øieged this day came ‚Äîover to us, and their Horse were all drawn this day into the Ca≈øtle-yard, & a certain number out of every Troop was chosen to be killed; and there were told in the Ca≈øtle Baily, 700 horse belonging to the Souldiers.

Thursday 20. They killed their horses; one Butcher ran away rather than he would do it. The Be≈øieged at night drew out their Horse at 12 of the clock, and afterwards at 2 of the clock in the morning to e≈øcape, but our men were in such readine≈øs they dur≈øt not advance.
Friday 21. News came of Captain Batten's Revolt to the Revolted Ships, de≈øerting the Parliament, and turning to the King.

Saturday 22. Severall Souldiers ran from the Be≈øieged, much complaining of their Diet in horse-fle≈øh, & a Trumpeter was this day sent in again to expedite ye Exchange of Sir Willm. Ma≈ø≈øam, for Mr. A≈øhburnham, but ye Be≈øieged refused it, as also to admit of ye exchange of the re≈øt of ye Committee, though they had Gentlemen of very good rank offered for them (quality for quality) in exchange.

Sunday 23. The Be≈øieged roa≈øted a horse near the North-bridge to make the Souldiers merry at ye entrance into ≈øuch Diet; this day our Generall had Intelligence of Col. Lamberts engagement with the Scots, near Appleby: where above 100 Scots were ≈ølain. Col. Harri≈øon & others on our part wounded.
Munday 24. Nothing of moment.

Tue≈øday 25. The Be≈øieged had a hot Alarm round the Town about 12 at night, and a partie in the meane time fired the Middle Mill, with the lo≈øs of three men, and cut off a ≈øluce, but the fire did not take, so the de≈øign proved ineffectuall at that time; at the same time we ≈øhot 20 Arrows, (with papers of advertisement offered) into the Town, to undeceive the Souldiers; acquainting them with what Conditions were offered them, and ≈øhall ≈øtill be made good unto them, if they come out: which coming to some of their knowledge above 200 came out by that day 7. night.
Wedne≈øday 26. Nothing of moment.

Thursday 27. A Troop of the Lord Capells ≈øallied out, and took 3 or 4 men as they were working upon the Line, near St. Botolphs, and wounded one mi≈øerably, being a Country Souldier & but a ≈øpectator.
Friday, Saturday, & Sunday 28. 29. & 30. Nothing of moment.

Munday 31. In the night about 20 of them with Spades, 6 only having Mu≈økets, pa≈øt the first Centinell as friends, ≈øaying, they were come to make an end of the work where they wrought the night before, but were fired upon at the second guard, had a Lieutenant slain, and retreated, and took a Serjeant with them pri≈øoner.
Tuesday August 1. A Cornet, Quarterma≈øter, Corporall, and one Trooper came away with their hor≈øes.

Wedne≈øday 2. & Thursday the third, there came severall Souldiers from the Be≈øieged, much complayning of their ill diet with horsefle≈øh, and said it was attended with Gentlewomen in white-Gownes & black hoods (meaning Maggots,) so that they could not eat it, & that it had brought many of them to the flux.
Monday Augu≈øt 7. Nothing of moment hapned: this day it was re≈øolved at a full Counsell of War, to proceed by way of Approaches in order to a Storm.
Friday 11. Nothing of note. This night 30 hou≈øes were burnt.
Tuesday 15. Many men came over this day from the Be≈øieged, & the poorer sort of people began to rise for want of bread.

Wednesday 16. They rise in great Numbers, and come to the Lord-Gorings Quarters, some bringing their Children ≈øtarved to death, they crying out so long as Horsefle≈øh, Dogs, and Cats were to be had, they did not complain. This day the Mayor of Colche≈øter sent a Letter to the Gen. That the Inhabitants might come out, for that they had no provi≈øion, it being all ≈øeised by the Souldiers. Our Generall returned an≈øwer, He pittied their condition, but to grant that, was to make the Town hold out longer, and did not ≈øtand with his tru≈øt to permit it. This day we had the news of the killing & di≈øpersing the Princes forces by some Hor≈øe and Foot of the Army, commanded by Col. Rich, near Deale; and also of the regaining of Tinmouth Ca≈øtle by Sir Arthur Ha≈øelrigg.

Thur≈øday 17. The Lord Goring, Lord Capell, and Sir Charles Lucas, who before threatned to hang our Trumpeter if he came any more with a Me≈ø≈øage for a Party, desired Our Generall they might send to the Kings Forces, and if they had not relief within 20 days, they would then Treat. Answer was returned by Our Gen. that he hop'd in much le≈øs time than 20 days, to have the Town without Treaty. All things are preparing in Order to a ≈øtorm.
Friday 18. No action but preparation for ≈øtorm.
Saturday 19. The Be≈øieged ≈øent for a Treaty to surrender.

Sunday 20. The Generall returned an answer to their offer for a Treaty, That all Souldiers & Officers under the degree of a Captain, (excepting such as have deserted the Army since the 10 of May last) ≈øhall have Pa≈ø≈øes to go to their severall homes; and all Captaines, and Superior Officers, with Lords, and Gentlemen to mercie.
Munday 21. The Be≈øieged turned out of the Town in the night, many men, women, & children, but the next morning took them in again.

Tue≈øday 22. The Be≈øieged sent out Major Sheffield one of the Committee that was prisoner in Colche≈øter, that they would surrender upon honourable conditions, and desire to know the meaning of ye word mercie. This day the news of routing the Scot≈øh army came, which we sent into the Town.

div.head: A Manu≈øcript of COLCHESTER taken out of the Records of the said Town.

list.item: Anno 219. Coell Duke of Brittanie began to build the Citty Raymore otherwise Colche≈øter.
Anno 238. Coell Duke of Colche≈øter began to Raigne over E≈ø≈øex and Hartford-≈øhire.
Anno 242. Helena Daughter of Coell was borne att Colche≈øter.
Anno 260. Con≈øtantius Captain of the Romanes in Spain comeing into Brittain be≈øieged Colche≈øter the space of two Years.
Anno 264. The Siege was Raised by a match Between Con≈øtantius and Helena.
Anno 265. Con≈øtantine the Son of Con≈øtantius was born in Colche≈øter.
Anno 288. Con≈øtantius then was called Cea≈øar of the Gaules.
Anno 289. Con≈øtantius when he had Slaine a considerable number of the Almaines that woar≈øted and over run Ga≈ø≈øia: being called Cea≈øar of the Gaules was now Saluted Cea≈øar Augu≈øtus.
Anno 290. Coell when he had Slaine A≈øclepodatus, the Tyrant Reigned over all Brittaine but was tributary to Rome. The same Coell Duke of Colche≈øter.
Anno 297. Coell King of Brittaine Dyed in Colche≈øter the Second Month.
Anno 298. Con≈øtantius Returning out of Gallia dispo≈øed of the Kingdome.
Anno 299. Con≈øtantinus the Emperor dyed at Yorke, in the Sixteenth Year of his Empire.
Anno 303. Helena upon the death of Con≈øtantinus made a ∆≤ow of perpetuall Widowhood.

div.p: Printed and Sold by Tho: Witham at the Golden Ball in Long Lane near West Smithfield LONDON
